TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy over sandy or sandy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Cumulic Endoaquolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Collegiate loam - grassland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--2 to 0 inch; an organic mat consisting primarily of undecomposed grass roots and remains.  (1 to 3 inches thick)
A11--0 to 9 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) light loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; moderate fine granular or crumb structure; soft, very friable; 10 percent gravel; neutral; gradual smooth boundary.  (0 to 14 inches thick)
A12g--9 to 36 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) light loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist, many medium prominent mottles, light olive brown (2.5Y 5/6) moist and dark gray (5Y 4/1) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure parting to weak granules; slightly hard, very friable, 10 percent gravel; noncalcareous; slightly alkaline; gradual wavy boundary.  (12 to 40 inches thick)
IICg--36 to 60 inches; noncalcareous very gravelly and cobbly sand.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Chaffee County, Colorado; 260 feet east and 220 feet north of the gate in the SW 1/4 of Sec. 26, T. 14 S., R. 78 W.; Buena Vista East Quadrangle; 38 degrees, 47 minutes, 52 seconds north latitude; 106 degrees, 4 minutes, 55 seconds west longitude.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The Collegiate soils typically are noncalcareous to depths of more than 60 inches but depth to uniformly calcareous material ranges from 40 to more than 60 inches.  The mollic epipedon ranges from 24 to 40 inches thick.  It typically extends to the IIC horizon, but mottled B2 horizons of low chroma occur in some pedons.  Depth to the sandy-skeletal IIC horizon ranges from 24 to 40 inches.  The upper part of the control section is typically light loam or very fine sandy loam and average 5 to 18 percent clay, 10 to 60 percent silt, and 22 to 75 percent sand, with less than 50 percent fine or coarser sand.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 35 percent by volume in a major part of the upper control section and are typically less than 3 inches in diameter, but range up to 10 inches in diameter.  The A and C horizons above a depth of 40 inches are neutral or slightly alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  There are no competing series.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Collegiate soils are on flood plains, low terraces, and old glacial outwash channels.  Slope gradient typically ranges from 0 to 6 percent.  The soil formed in alluvial or glacial outwash parent materials derived from various sources.  At the type location the average annual precipitation is 12 inches, with peak periods of precipitation in the spring and summer.  The mean annual temperature is 42 degrees F, and the mean summer temperature is 61 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Antero and Gas Creek soils.  Antero soils lack mollic epipedons.  Gas Creek soils are coarse textured and have mollic epipedons less than 24 inches thick.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly to somewhat poorly drained; low runoff; moderate permeability.  They have a permanent to fluctuating water table.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used principally as native pastureland or as native hay meadow.  Principal native vegetation is water-tolerant grasses and sedges.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  High mountain valleys in Central Colorado.  This series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 3/99.
